elements.title: Marie Séraphique (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that "the most accurate contemporary picture of conditions" on slave ships is an illustration of the Marie Séraphique (pictured)?

elements.title: Cack Henley (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Cack Henley threw the longest complete game shutout in professional baseball history?

elements.title: places of worship in the English district of East Hampshire (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that places of worship in the English district of East Hampshire include the Temple of the White Eagle Lodge—likened to "an Art Deco version of the Pantheon"?

elements.title: Bill Pinkney (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Bill Pinkney was the first African American to sail around the world solo via the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Horn?

elements.title: Operation Romeo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Operation Romeo was one of the causes of the Nepalese Civil War?

elements.title: Stony Island (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that after decades of being a central hub for river dredging operations, Stony Island's population was reduced to a caretaker and his two dogs?

elements.title: Louise Potiki Bryant (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that New Zealand choreographer and dancer Louise Potiki Bryant was coated in clay by sculptor Paerau Corneal in their interdisciplinary work Kiri?

elements.title: Bayshore Route (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that street racing was once prevalent along the Tokyo area's Bayshore Route?
